elements.content: Reactions in water of lanthanide chlorides with the sodium salt of 1,4-carboxyphenylboronic acid lead to two series of isostructural compounds with respective general chemical formulas [Ln­(cpb)3(H2O)2]∞ for Ln = La or Ce and [Ln­(cpbOH)­(H2O)2·(cpb)]∞ for Ln = Pr–Lu (except Pm) plus Y. Heterolanthanide coordination polymers that are isostructural to the second series have been synthesized, and their photophysical properties have been studied. This study evidences that it is possible to design multiemissive lanthanide-based coordination polymers that could find their application as multigauge luminescent thermometric probes.

Heterolanthanide coordination polymers that are isostructural to the second series have been synthesized, and their photophysical properties have been studied. This study evidences that it is possible to design multiemissive lanthanide-based coordination polymers that could find their application as multigauge luminescent thermometric probes.

elements.content: In the last two decades, there was a growing interest for lanthanide-based coordination polymers because of their fascinating crystal structures as well as their interesting porosity, magnetic, and optical properties. Because of their unique optical properties, lanthanide-based coordination polymers can be suitable for potential applications in various fields, such as lighting and display, chemical sensing, fight against counterfeiting, or thermometric probes, for example. Some of these applications require the use of heterolanthanide coordination polymers whose first example has been reported in 1994 by Zhou et al. Our group is involved in that field for more than a decade, and the search of new ligands that lead to new heterolanthanide coordination polymers with original luminescence properties is a continuous concern.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the last two decades, there was a growing interest for lanthanide-based coordination polymers because of their fascinating crystal structures as well as their interesting porosity, magnetic, and optical properties. Because of their unique optical properties, lanthanide-based coordination polymers can be suitable for potential applications in various fields, such as lighting and display, chemical sensing, fight against counterfeiting, or thermometric probes, for example. Some of these applications require the use of heterolanthanide coordination polymers whose first example has been reported in 1994 by Zhou et al. Our group is involved in that field for more than a decade, and the search of new ligands that lead to new heterolanthanide coordination polymers with original luminescence properties is a continuous concern.

elements.content: This article is devoted to the study of heterolanthanide-based coordination polymers with 4-carboxyphenylboronic acid (Hcpb) as ligand (). This ligand has been chosen because of its rodelike topology, low toxicity, and ability to behave as both Lewis and Brønsted acids. Moreover, it can act as a structuring ligand via π-stacking and hydrogen bonds. At last, examples of coordination compounds based on boronate ligands are rather scarce and to the best of our knowledge, there are to date only two examples of lanthanide-based coordination polymers with such ligands.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representation of the 1,4-Carboxyphenylboronic Acid Hereafter Symbolized by Hcpb

elements.content: 1,4-Carboxyphenylboronic acid (Hcpb) (>90%) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without any further purification. By recrystallization in water, two different polymorphous phases were isolated depending on the recrystallization process. One out of the two crystal structures was still unknown. It has the chemical formula Hcpb·0.25H2O. Its crystal and final structure refinement data as well as projection views of the asymmetric unit and of the crystal packing are reported in Table S1 and Figures S1 and S2, respectively. Crystal structure of Hcpb has been reported previously (CCDC-247776). This very rich polymorphic system (four different crystal structures reported to date) confirms that this ligand is able to provide various structuring intermolecular interactions (). Powder diffraction diagram and thermal analysis of the commercial microcrystalline powder revealed that it is isostructural to Hcpb (Figures S3 and S4).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis and Characterization of the Starting Salts

1,4-Carboxyphenylboronic acid (Hcpb) (>90%) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without any further purification. By recrystallization in water, two different polymorphous phases were isolated depending on the recrystallization process. One out of the two crystal structures was still unknown. It has the chemical formula Hcpb⋅0.25H2O. Its crystal and final structure refinement data as well as projection views of the asymmetric unit and of the crystal packing are reported in Table S1 and Figures S1 and S2, respectively. Crystal structure of Hcpb has been reported previously (CCDC-247776). This very rich polymorphic system (four different crystal structures reported to date) confirms that this ligand is able to provide various structuring intermolecular interactions (). Powder diffraction diagram and thermal analysis of the commercial microcrystalline powder revealed that it is isostructural to Hcpb (Figures S3 and S4).

Sodium salt of 1,4-carboxyphenylboronic acid was prepared by addition of 1 equiv of sodium hydroxide to a suspension of the acid in water. The pH was then adjusted to 9 by another addition of sodium hydroxide to the mixture. The obtained clear solution was then evaporated to dryness, and the resulting solid washed with ethanol. Precipitation occurred after ethoxyethane addition. The precipitate was then filtered and dried in air. The yield was about 90%. Thermal analyses show that the salt is Nacpb·1.5H2O (Figure S5).
elements.clean_text: Sodium salt of 1,4-carboxyphenylboronic acid was prepared by addition of 1 equiv of sodium hydroxide to a suspension of the acid in water. The pH was then adjusted to 9 by another addition of sodium hydroxide to the mixture. The obtained clear solution was then evaporated to dryness, and the resulting solid washed with ethanol. Precipitation occurred after ethoxyethane addition. The precipitate was then filtered and dried in air. The yield was about 90%. Thermal analyses show that the salt is Nacpb⋅1.5H2O (Figure S5).

elements.content: Some single crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by recrystallization in water. In this crystal structure, the sodium salt is twice hydrated (Nacpb·2H2O). Crystal and final structure refinement data as well as a projection view of the asymmetric unit are reported in Table S2 and Figure S6.

elements.content:
Lanthanide oxides (4 N) were purchased from AMPERE Company and used without further purification. Lanthanide chlorides were prepared according to established procedures.

Synthesis of the Lanthanide-Based Coordination Polymers as Microcrystalline Powders

Homolanthanide-based coordination polymers were obtained by mixing stoichiometric amounts of a lanthanide chloride and the sodium salt of 1,4-carboxyphenylboronic acid in water under ambient pressure and temperature. Precipitation immediately occurred. Precipitates were filtered, rinsed with water, and dried in air. The yields were close to 90%. On the basis of their powder X-ray diffraction diagrams, microcrystalline powders were classified in two families of isostructural compounds depending on the involved lanthanide ion (Figure S7): compounds with general chemical formula [Ln­(cpb)3(H2O)2]∞ (hereafter abbreviated as [Ln­(cpb)3]∞) were obtained for Ln = La or Ce, whereas for Ln = Pr–Lu (except Pm) plus Y, compounds have general chemical formula [Ln­(cpbOH)­(H2O)2·(cpb)]∞ that is hereafter abbreviated as [Ln­(cpbOH)]∞. Crystal structure of compounds that constitutes the former family is described hereafter. Crystal structure of compounds of the latter family has previously been described.
elements.clean_text:
Lanthanide oxides (4 N) were purchased from AMPERE Company and used without further purification. Lanthanide chlorides were prepared according to established procedures. 

Synthesis of the Lanthanide-Based Coordination Polymers as Microcrystalline Powders

Homolanthanide-based coordination polymers were obtained by mixing stoichiometric amounts of a lanthanide chloride and the sodium salt of 1,4-carboxyphenylboronic acid in water under ambient pressure and temperature. Precipitation immediately occurred. Precipitates were filtered, rinsed with water, and dried in air. The yields were close to 90%. On the basis of their powder X-ray diffraction diagrams, microcrystalline powders were classified in two families of isostructural compounds depending on the involved lanthanide ion (Figure S7): compounds with general chemical formula [Ln(cpb)3(H2O)2]∞ (hereafter abbreviated as [Ln(cpb)3]∞) were obtained for Ln = La or Ce, whereas for Ln = Pr-Lu (except Pm) plus Y, compounds have general chemical formula [Ln(cpbOH)(H2O)2⋅(cpb)]∞ that is hereafter abbreviated as [Ln(cpbOH)]∞. Crystal structure of compounds that constitutes the former family is described hereafter. Crystal structure of compounds of the latter family has previously been described.

elements.content: Heterolanthanide-based coordination polymers were synthesized according to the same procedure by simply replacing the lanthanide chloride solution by a mixture of lanthanide chloride solution. All heterolanthanide compounds have been assumed to be isostructural to [Tb­(cpbOH)]∞ on the basis of their powder X-ray diffraction diagrams (Figures S8–S14). For all of them, relative contents of the different lanthanide ions have been estimated by energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) measurements (Table S3). On the basis of previous 89Y solid-state NMR spectroscopy studies realized on similar compounds, it has been assumed that lanthanide ions are randomly distributed over all metallic sites of the crystal structure.

All heterolanthanide compounds have been assumed to be isostructural to [Tb(cpbOH)]∞  on the basis of their powder X-ray diffraction diagrams (Figures S8-S14). For all of them, relative contents of the different lanthanide ions have been estimated by energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) measurements (Table S3). On the basis of previous 89Y solid-state NMR spectroscopy studies realized on similar compounds, it has been assumed that lanthanide ions are randomly distributed over all metallic sites of the crystal structure.

elements.content:
Tetramethylorthosilicate (TMOS) was purchased from Acros Organics and jellified according to established procedures.

Aqueous solutions of a lanthanum chloride on one hand and of the sodium salt of 1,4-carboxyphenylboronic acid on the other hand were allowed to slowly diffuse through a TMOS gel (7.5% in weight) in a U-shaped tube. After a few weeks, needlelike single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were collected and sealed in capillaries to avoid any potential dehydration.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Growth of the Single Crystals of [La(cpb)3]∞ 

Tetramethylorthosilicate (TMOS) was purchased from Acros Organics and jellified according to established procedures. 

Aqueous solutions of a lanthanum chloride on one hand and of the sodium salt of 1,4-carboxyphenylboronic acid on the other hand were allowed to slowly diffuse through a TMOS gel (7.5% in weight) in a U-shaped tube. After a few weeks, needlelike single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were collected and sealed in capillaries to avoid any potential dehydration.

elements.content: Single crystals were mounted on a Nonius Kappa CCD Bruker diffractometer for [La­(cpb)3]∞ and on a D8 Venture Bruker diffractometer for the other compounds. Crystal data collections were performed with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.70713 Å) at room temperature for [La­(cpb)3]∞ and Nacpb·2H2O and at 150 K for the other compound. Crystal structures were solved by direct methods using SIR97 program and then refined with full matrix least-squares method based on F 2 (SHELX97) with the aid of WINGX program. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using the SHELXL program. Hydrogen atoms bound to the organic ligand were located at ideal positions except those of the −B­(OH)3 groups in [La­(cpb)3]∞ crystal structure. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were not localized. Absorption correction was performed using WinGX program facilities. Full details of the X-ray structure determination of the crystal structures of Hcpb·0.25H2O, Nacpb·2H2O, and [La­(cpb)3]∞ have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center under the depositary numbers CCDC-1843158, CCDC-1843156, and CCDC-962509 respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Single crystals were mounted on a Nonius Kappa CCD Bruker diffractometer for [La(cpb)3]∞ and on a D8 Venture Bruker diffractometer for the other compounds. Crystal data collections were performed with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.70713 Å) at room temperature for [La(cpb)3]∞ and Nacpb⋅2H2O and at 150 K for the other compound. Crystal structures were solved by direct methods using SIR97 program and then refined with full matrix least-squares method based on F 2 (SHELX97) with the aid of WINGX program. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using the SHELXL program. Hydrogen atoms bound to the organic ligand were located at ideal positions except those of the -B(OH)3 groups in [La(cpb)3]∞ crystal structure. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were not localized. Absorption correction was performed using WinGX program facilities. Full details of the X-ray structure determination of the crystal structures of Hcpb⋅0.25H2O, Nacpb⋅2H2O, and [La(cpb)3]∞ have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center under the depositary numbers CCDC-1843158, CCDC-1843156, and CCDC-962509 respectively.

elements.content: Experimental diagrams have been collected with a Panalytical X’pert Pro diffractometer equipped with an X’Celerator detector (45 kV, 40 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) in θ/θ mode). Calculated diagrams were produced using Powdercell and WinPLOTR software programs.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

Experimental diagrams have been collected with a Panalytical X'pert Pro diffractometer equipped with an X'Celerator detector (45 kV, 40 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) in θ/θ mode). Calculated diagrams were produced using Powdercell and WinPLOTR software programs.

elements.content: Luminescence spectra (emission and excitation) have been realized on a Horiba Jobin Yvon Fluorolog III fluorescence spectrometer. This device has been equipped with a Xe lamp 450 W, a UV–vis photomultiplier (PMT Hamamatsu R928, sensitivity range = 190–860 nm), and an infrared (IR) photodiode cooled by liquid nitrogen (InGaAs, sensitivity range = 800–1600 nm). Classical emission and excitation have been measured in the solid state at room temperature. Quantum yields were measured using an integrating sphere from Jobin Yvon company owing to the following formula: Φ = (E c – E a)/(L a – L c) (E c and L c are the integrated emission spectrum and the absorption at the excitation wavelength of the sample, whereas E a and L a are the integrated “blank” emission spectrum and “blank” absorption, respectively). Quantum yield recordings and emission/excitation spectra were performed on powder samples introduced in cylindrical quartz cells of 2.4 cm height and 0.7 cm diameter, which were placed inside the integrating sphere. For the IR emissions, powder samples were pasted on copper plates with silver glue or introduced directly in quartz capillary tubes. The Gd-based phospholuminescence has been realized at 77 K; the powder was placed in a quartz capillary tube, which was introduced inside a small Dewar filled by liquid nitrogen. Emissions and excitations at variable temperature were performed with an optical cryostat coupled with an external liquid nitrogen bath, able to reach the temperature of 77 K under nitrogen gas media. Luminescence decays were measured at room temperature using a xenon flash lamp (phosphorescence mode) from the Fluorolog III spectrometer. Quantum yields and luminescence decays are averages of two or three independent determinations.

Optical Measurements

elements.content: Comparative solid-state luminescent spectra have been measured on powder samples shaped into pellets using the Fluorolog III fluorescence spectrometer between 450 and 725 nm under identical operating conditions. The xenon lamp was maintained as switched on during all measurements to ensure a valid comparison between the emission spectra.

The xenon lamp was maintained as switched on during all measurements to ensure a valid comparison between the emission spectra.

elements.content: For all measurements recorded, the residual excitation laser light, the Rayleigh scattered light, and associated harmonics from spectra (emission, excitation, decay, and quantum yield) were removed with appropriate filters. All spectra were corrected for the instrumental response function.
elements.clean_text: For all measurements recorded, the residual excitation laser light, the Rayleigh scattered light, and associated harmonics from spectra (emission, excitation, decay, and quantum yield) were removed with appropriate filters. All spectra were corrected for the instrumental response function.

elements.content: Luminescence intensities (in Cd m–2) of the powders have been measured using a Gigahertz Optik X1-1 optometer (integration time = 200 ms) on 1.5 cm2 pellets under UV irradiation (λexc = 312 nm). The UV flux (in mW cm–2) at the sample location has been measured using a VilberLourmat VLX-3W radiometer. [Tb2(bdc)3·4H2O]∞ compound where bdc2– stands for terephthalate was used as a reference. Its luminance value is 107 Cd m–2 under 312 nm irradiation and a flux of 0.793 mW cm–2.

elements.content:
Solution and solid-state UV–visible absorption spectra have been recorded using a PerkinElmer Lambda 650 spectrometer equipped with a 60 mm integrated sphere.

Colorimetric Measurements

The Commission Internationale de l′Eclairage (CIE: 2°, CIE 1931, step 5 nm) (x, y) emission color coordinates were measured using a MSU-003 colorimeter with PhotonProbe 1.6.0 Software from Majantys. Color measurements were realized under 312 nm UV light: X = k × ∫ 380 nm 780 nm I λ × x λ , Y = k × ∫ 780 nm 380 nm I λ × y λ , and Z = k × ∫ 780 nm 380 nm I λ × z λ , with k, constant for the measurement system; I λ, sample spectrum intensity wavelength; and x λ, y λ, and z λ, trichromatic values x = X/(X + Y + Z), y = Y/(X + Y + Z), and z = Z/(X + Y + Z). Mean xyz values are given for each sample, which act as light sources (luminescent samples). Standards from Phosphor Technology were used for calibration at 312 nm: red phosphor Gd2O2S:Eu (x = 0.667, y = 0.330) and green phosphor Gd2O2S:Tb (x = 0.328, y = 0.537).

elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analyses

Thermal analyses were performed with a PerkinElmer STA6000 thermogravimetric/differential scanning calorimetry (TG/DSC) analyzer in the 20-900 °C temperature range under N2 atmosphere in ceramic crucibles.

elements.content: EDS measurements have been performed with a Hitachi TM-1000 Tabletop Microscope version 02.11 (Hitachi High-Technologies, Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) with EDS analysis system (SwiftED-TM, Oxford Instruments Link INCA). Samples were deposited on carbon disks pasted on an aluminum stub located at 7 mm from EDX beam, with an angle of measurement of 22°. Reproducibility of the elemental analyses has been checked by repeating the measurements several times. These experiments support the homogeneity of the samples.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Microscopy and Energy-Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS)

EDS measurements have been performed with a Hitachi TM-1000 Tabletop Microscope version 02.11 (Hitachi High-Technologies, Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) with EDS analysis system (SwiftED-TM, Oxford Instruments Link INCA). Samples were deposited on carbon disks pasted on an aluminum stub located at 7 mm from EDX beam, with an angle of measurement of 22°. Reproducibility of the elemental analyses has been checked by repeating the measurements several times. These experiments support the homogeneity of the samples.

elements.content: Reactions in water of lanthanide chlorides and the sodium salt of 1,4-carboxyphenylboronic lead to two families of isostructural compounds depending on the involved lanthanide ion: [Ln­(cpb)3]∞ with Ln = La–Ce and [Ln­(cpbOH)]∞ with Ln = Pr–Lu (except Pm) plus Y (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Reactions in water of lanthanide chlorides and the sodium salt of 1,4-carboxyphenylboronic lead to two families of isostructural compounds depending on the involved lanthanide ion: [Ln(cpb)3]∞ with Ln = La-Ce and [Ln(cpbOH)]∞ with Ln = Pr-Lu (except Pm) plus Y (Figure S7).

elements.content: La3+- and Ce3+-based coordination polymers have the general abbreviated chemical formula [Ln­(cpb)3]∞, where Ln = La or Ce. Crystal structure has been solved on the basis of the lanthanum-containing derivative. Crystal and final structure refinement data of the crystal structure are listed in .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of [Ln(cpb)3]∞ with Ln = La-Ce

La3+- and Ce3+-based coordination polymers have the general abbreviated chemical formula [Ln(cpb)3]∞, where Ln = La or Ce. Crystal structure has been solved on the basis of the lanthanum-containing derivative. Crystal and final structure refinement data of the crystal structure are listed in .

The crystal structure can be described as the superimposition of one-dimensional double-chained molecular motifs that spread along b axis. Molecular motifs are held together by a strong hydrogen-bond network that involves −OH groups of the boronic functions (d O–O ≈ 2.77 Å) on one hand and the coordination water molecules (d O–O = 2.84 Å) on the other hand ().

Molecular motifs are held together by a strong hydrogen-bond network that involves -OH groups of the boronic functions (d O-O ~ 2.77 Å) on one hand and the coordination water molecules (d O-O = 2.84 Å) on the other hand ().

elements.content: There is only one independent La3+ ion in the crystal structure. It is eight-coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six carboxylate functions from different cpb– ligands and by two oxygen atoms from coordination water molecules that generate a biaugmented trigonal prism (C 2v site symmetry). There are three independent cpb– ligands, but all three adopt the same bridging coordination mode (): the carboxylate function links two different La3+ ions in a unidentate manner, whereas the boronic function is free and only involved in the interchained hydrogen-bond network.

There are three independent cpb- ligands, but all three adopt the same bridging coordination mode (): the carboxylate function links two different La3+ ions in a unidentate manner, whereas the boronic function is free and only involved in the interchained hydrogen-bond network.

elements.content: Coordination polymers that are obtained with one of the rare earth elements between praseodymium and lutetium (except promethium) or yttrium are all isostructural with [Tb­(cpbOH)]∞ whose crystal structure has been reported previously (CCDC-962513). Its crystal structure is two dimensional and can be described on the basis of wavy planes that spread parallel to the ab plane. In the interplanar space, isolated cpb– ligands insure the electroneutrality of the crystal packing (see ).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of [Ln(cpbOH)]∞ with Ln = Pr-Lu (Except Pm) Plus Y

Coordination polymers that are obtained with one of the rare earth elements between praseodymium and lutetium (except promethium) or yttrium are all isostructural with [Tb(cpbOH)]∞ whose crystal structure has been reported previously (CCDC-962513). Its crystal structure is two dimensional and can be described on the basis of wavy planes that spread parallel to the ab plane. In the interplanar space, isolated cpb- ligands insure the electroneutrality of the crystal packing (see ).

elements.content: As far as luminescent properties are targeted, this second family of compounds is the most interesting one because it contains all lanthanide ions that can emit in the visible or near-IR (NIR) regions. As a consequence, intermetallic distances between lanthanide ions have to be carefully considered because they influence intermetallic energy-transfer efficiency. In this crystal structure, chains of lanthanide ions spread along a axis. In these chains, shortest distances between neighboring lanthanide ions are 5.3 and 4.3 Å. These chains are bound to each other by cpb– ligands to form wavy molecular planes. The shortest distance between lanthanide ions that belong to neighboring chains is 9.8 Å. Last, the shortest distance between lanthanide ions that belong to different wavy planes is 9.6 Å. For estimating the mean distance between lanthanide ions in the crystal structure, it is possible to use the rough model that has already been used successfully previously. In this model, the mean volume occupied by a lanthanide ion is calculated as the cell volume (3588 Å3) divided by the number of lanthanide ions in the unit cell (Z = 8). This mean volume corresponds to a sphere with a 4.75 Å radius, which suggests that the mean distance between two lanthanide ions is roughly 9.5 Å. Therefore, according to this model, a dilution by 10% of the optically active lanthanide ions would reduce significantly intermetallic energy transfers. Indeed, it is usually considered that intermetallic energy transfers become less efficient when there is no acceptor lanthanide ion closer than 10 Å from a given lanthanide ion. This can be achieved by dilution of optically active lanthanide ions by nonacceptor lanthanide ions (such as Gd3+, Y3+, or Lu3+ for instance).

These chains are bound to each other by cpb- ligands to form wavy molecular planes. The shortest distance between lanthanide ions that belong to neighboring chains is 9.8 Å. Last, the shortest distance between lanthanide ions that belong to different wavy planes is 9.6 Å. For estimating the mean distance between lanthanide ions in the crystal structure, it is possible to use the rough model that has already been used successfully previously. In this model, the mean volume occupied by a lanthanide ion is calculated as the cell volume (3588 Å3) divided by the number of lanthanide ions in the unit cell (Z = 8). This mean volume corresponds to a sphere with a 4.75 Å radius, which suggests that the mean distance between two lanthanide ions is roughly 9.5 Å. Therefore, according to this model, a dilution by 10% of the optically active lanthanide ions would reduce significantly intermetallic energy transfers. Indeed, it is usually considered that intermetallic energy transfers become less efficient when there is no acceptor lanthanide ion closer than 10 Å from a given lanthanide ion. This can be achieved by dilution of optically active lanthanide ions by nonacceptor lanthanide ions (such as Gd3+, Y3+, or Lu3+ for instance).

elements.content: However, shows that the 9.5 Å mean intermetallic distance is overestimated in the present case. Indeed, it does not reflect the anisotropic character of the lanthanide-ion distribution in the crystal structure. Actually, from a global point of view, for a given lanthanide ion, eight other lanthanide ions are closer than 10 Å and two out of the eight are much closer (4.3–5.3 Å) than the six others (9.6–9.8 Å) (). Therefore, a dilution of more than 50% is necessary for embedding energy transfers between neighboring lanthanide ions that belong to the same molecular chain, and a dilution of almost 90% for insuring insulation of a given lanthanide ion from other acceptor lanthanide ions.

Solid-State Luminescence Properties of Homolanthanide Coordination Polymers [Ln(cpbOH)]∞ with Ln = Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, or Ho

Energies of the lowest excited singlet and triplet states of the ligand have been estimated by referring, respectively, to the wavelength of the excitation edge (E 1π-1π*  = 325 nm = 30750 cm-1) and to the shortest wavelength phosphorescent band (E 1π-3π*  = 400 nm = 25000 cm-1) of [Gd(cpbOH)]∞ (Figure S15).

elements.content: According to Reinhoudt’s empirical rule, the intersystem crossing process becomes effective when ΔE (1ππ*–3ππ*) is at least 5000 cm–1. In this compound, the gap between the singlet and the triplet excited state (5750 cm–1) is favorable for an efficient intersystem crossing process.
elements.clean_text: According to Reinhoudt's empirical rule, the intersystem crossing process becomes effective when ΔE (1ππ*-3ππ*) is at least 5000 cm-1. In this compound, the gap between the singlet and the triplet excited state (5750 cm-1) is favorable for an efficient intersystem crossing process.

elements.content: Solid-state luminescent properties have been recorded in visible or near-IR regions for [Ln­(cpbOH)]∞ with Ln = Nd, Sm, Eu, Tb, Dy, and Ho. These measurements show that an antenna effect is observed for all compounds. Most emitting homolanthanide compounds are those which are based on Nd3+, Eu3+, or Tb3+ (). This is in agreement with Latva’s empirical rule that predicts that the energy of the first excited triplet state (25 000 cm–1) allows good ligand-to-metal energy transfer without significant back transfer for Tb3+ (5D4 → 7F6–0 transitions) and Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F0–4 transitions). Despite its low luminescent energy level, an antenna effect is also observed for the Nd3+-based compound (4F3/2 → 4I9/2, 4I11/2, 4I13/2 transitions) ().

Excitation and emission spectra of [Ln­(cpbOH)]∞ with Ln = Sm3+, Dy3+, or Ho3+ are reported in (Figure S16). Their weak luminescence can be related to their small energy gaps. Overall luminescent quantum yields and observed lifetime for both the Eu- and the Tb-based homolanthanide compounds have been measured. They are reported in . These results complete and confirm previously reported results about Tb- and Eu-derivatives.

Because thermometric probe application is targeted, dependence upon temperature of solid-state luminescence of the three most luminescent homonuclear compounds has been studied in the 77–293 K range (). In the following, luminescence intensity of a given lanthanide ion will be assumed to be proportional to the integrated intensity of the most intense characteristic emission peak of this lanthanide ion, that is, the one centered at 544.5 nm for Tb3+ (5D4 → 7F5), 611.5 nm for Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2), and 1055 nm for Nd3+ (4F3/2 → 4I11/2). It will be symbolized hereafter by I Ln.

Because thermometric probe application is targeted, dependence upon temperature of solid-state luminescence of the three most luminescent homonuclear compounds has been studied in the 77-293 K range (). In the following, luminescence intensity of a given lanthanide ion will be assumed to be proportional to the integrated intensity of the most intense characteristic emission peak of this lanthanide ion, that is, the one centered at 544.5 nm for Tb3+ (5D4 → 7F5), 611.5 nm for Eu3+ (5D0 → 7F2), and 1055 nm for Nd3+ (4F3/2 → 4I11/2). It will be symbolized hereafter by I Ln.

elements.content: shows that luminescence of homonuclear Nd3+-based compound is only weakly influenced by temperature whereas the one of the homonuclear Eu3+-based compound decreases when temperature increases. This decrease is not surprising and can be related to the increase of vibrational-based nonradiative de-excitation. On the contrary, evidences that luminescence intensity of the homonuclear Tb3+-based compound increases when temperature increases. This behavior is quite rare but has already been observed.

elements.content: Four families of heterolanthanide compounds have been synthesized: [Tb1–x Gd x (cpbOH)]∞, [Eu1–x Gd x (cpbOH)]∞, [Tb1–x Eu x (cpbOH)]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 1, and [Gd0.2Tb0.8–x Eu x (cpbOH)]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.8. All compounds that constitute these series have been assumed to be isostructural to [Tb­(cpbOH)]∞ on the basis of their powder diffraction diagrams (Figures S8–S11). Relative contents of the lanthanide ions have been measured by EDS, and they are reported in Table S3. On the basis of previous results obtained on similar systems, it has been assumed that lanthanide ions are randomly distributed over the metallic sites of the crystal structure.
elements.clean_text: Four families of heterolanthanide compounds have been synthesized: [Tb1-x Gd x (cpbOH)]∞, [Eu1-x Gd x (cpbOH)]∞, [Tb1-x Eu x (cpbOH)]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 1, and [Gd0.2Tb0.8-x Eu x (cpbOH)]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.8. All compounds that constitute these series have been assumed to be isostructural to [Tb(cpbOH)]∞ on the basis of their powder diffraction diagrams (Figures S8-S11). Relative contents of the lanthanide ions have been measured by EDS, and they are reported in Table S3. On the basis of previous results obtained on similar systems, it has been assumed that lanthanide ions are randomly distributed over the metallic sites of the crystal structure.

elements.content: For both systems, these measurements are quite different from what is usually observed. Actually, as Gd3+ content increases, an abrupt increase of the luminescence intensity is not observed. This is probably related to the very short intermetallic distances along the a crystallographic axis (4.3–5.3 Å). Indeed, intermetallic energy-transfer efficiency highly depends on intermetallic distance and it has been demonstrated that presence of “dimeric” units induces very efficient intermetallic energy transfer even when average intermetallic distance is important. On the other hand, luminescence intensity is almost unchanged from x = 0.1 to 0.8, which indicates that the decrease of optically active lanthanide ion content (Tb3+ or Eu3+) is compensated by the diminution of intermetallic energy transfer. This suggests that intermetallic energy transfer is strong and that dilution by nonacceptor lanthanide ion (Gd3+) is efficient over a large range of dilution rates. This is in quite good agreement with the fact that for a given lanthanide ion, there are eight lanthanide ions that are closer than 10 Å in the crystal structure.

elements.content: To estimate Tb3+-to-Eu3+ energy transfer, luminescence spectra of [Tb1–x Eu x (cpbOH)]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 1 have been measured (). These measurements show an efficient Tb3+-to-Eu3+ energy transfer as soon as x becomes greater than 0.1. To quantify the efficiency of this intermetallic transfer (ηET), luminescence lifetimes of [Tb1–x Eu x (cpbOH)]∞ and [Tb1–x Gd x (cpbOH)]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 1 have been measured and relationship has been used (see )­ η ET = 1 − τ obs τ 0 where τobs and τ0 are the observed luminescent lifetimes of Tb3+ in presence (τobs) and absence (τ0) of an acceptor ion (Eu3+).

and show that intermetallic energy transfer reaches a plateau for x ≈ 0.2 and then remains almost constant. This quite moderate value of the calculated intermetallic energy-transfer efficiency (ηET ≈ 45%) was unexpected. Indeed, colorimetric coordinates of [Tb1–x Eu x (cpbOH)]∞ () evidence a very efficient Tb3+-to-Eu3+ energy transfer that compares well with what was observed in previously reported systems for which ηET was about 90%. This is probably related to the anisotropic character of the metallic distribution in this crystal structure.

elements.content: To estimate the effect of optical dilution in this Eu/Tb system, a series of compounds with respective general chemical formulas [Tb1–x Eu x (cpbOH)]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 1 and [Gd0.2Tb0.8–x Eu x (cpbOH)]∞ with 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.8 were compared on the basis of their luminance and colorimetric coordinates under UV irradiation and luminescence spectra (). This comparison evidences that dilution by 20% of Gd3+ ions reduces significantly intermetallic energy transfer and allows observing both characteristic emissions of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions under unique UV irradiation.

elements.content: Evaluation of the sensitivity of molecular thermometers is calculated by the following relationship S = ∂ P ∂ T P where P is the temperature-dependent parameter that has been chosen (luminescence intensity, luminescence lifetime, or luminescence intensity ratio, for instance). Therefore, in the present case, relationship becomes S = ∂ ( I Tb / I Eu ) ∂ T I Tb / I Eu With this relationship, the maximum sensitivity for this system is 1.18% K–1 centered at 130 K in the 77–300 K temperature range (Figure S17). This value is in agreement with what has previously been reported for other systems.

elements.content: However, also evidences that this compound is not optimized as far as thermometer probes are targeted. Indeed, for both Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions, luminescence intensities decrease as the temperature increases. Moreover, variation of Tb3+ intensity is moderate and the curve I Tb versus T is almost flat. Finally, relative luminescence intensity of Tb3+ is low (0% < I Tb normalized < 6%), which induces a low accuracy of its determination.

elements.content: To increase I Tb, optically diluted analogous [Gd0.2Tb0.7Eu0.1(cpbOH)]∞ was synthesized and its emission spectra were recorded between 77 K and room temperature (). As expected, I Tb is much greater (45% < I Tb normalized< 85%) than in the previous compound. Moreover, luminescence intensity of Tb3+ and of Eu3+ do not vary in the same way anymore: as the temperature increases, Eu3+ luminescence intensity slightly oscillates between 77 and 300 K, with a maximum at 160 K and a minimum at 250 K, whereas the one of Tb3+ decreases continuously over the whole temperature range.

elements.content: Since intermetallic energy transfer can be modulated by optical dilution in this system, dual visible and IR emission can be targeted. This is the reason why [Tb0.95Nd0.05(cpbOH)]∞ and [Gd0.20Tb0.75Nd0.05(cpbOH)]∞ have been synthesized (Figure S12 and Table S3). Their luminescence spectra were recorded at room temperature (). In both cases, characteristic luminescence of both Tb3+ and Nd3+ ions was observed. To the best of our knowledge, this is quite rare because most often, the presence of Nd3+ provokes a quenching of Tb3+ luminescence.

elements.content: evidences a complex competition between energy-transfer mechanisms. Indeed, Eu3+ luminescence abruptly decreases for 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.2. This decreasing is accompanied by an increasing of Nd3+ luminescence. This is in agreement with an efficient Eu3+-to-Nd3+ energy transfer. However, for x values comprised between 0.2 and 0.8, Nd3+ luminescence is almost constant. Then, it abruptly increases for x values comprised between 0.8 and 1. This behavior was unexpected and suggests a Nd3+-to-Eu3+ energy back transfer.

It can also be noticed that comparison between , , , and evidences that in this system, intermetallic energy transfer is strongly dependent on the temperature and the system composition ().

Conclusions and Outlooks

Compounds that are described in this paper present strong intermetallic energy transfers and quite intense and temperature-dependent emissions for Tb3+, Eu3+, and Nd3+ ions. The anisotropic nature of the metallic distribution in the material makes the optical dilution by Gd3+ ions efficient. Indeed, multiple emissions are achievable for 20% Gd3+ content. These results demonstrate that it is possible to modulate intermetallic energy transfer and to design compounds that emit, under a unique excitation wavelength, in both visible and infrared regions.

Conclusions and Outlooks

Compounds that are described in this paper present strong intermetallic energy transfers and quite intense and temperature-dependent emissions for Tb3+, Eu3+, and Nd3+ ions. The anisotropic nature of the metallic distribution in the material makes the optical dilution by Gd3+ ions efficient. Indeed, multiple emissions are achievable for 20% Gd3+ content. These results demonstrate that it is possible to modulate intermetallic energy transfer and to design compounds that emit, under a unique excitation wavelength, in both visible and infrared regions.
